long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem:
Latest update of Ox broke multi_xml test suite:

https://apps.fedoraproject.org/koschei/package/rubygem-multi_xml?collection=f26

The question is what if this is issue of the test suite of multi_xml really produces wrong results using latest Ox.


Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
rubygem-ox-2.4.13-1.fc26
rubygem-multi_xml-0.6.0-2.fc26


How reproducible:


Steps to Reproduce:
1.
2.
3.

Actual results:


Expected results:


Additional info:
Not sure if it should be fixed on Ox or multi_xml side ...

The commit in Ox causing it:

https://github.com/ohler55/ox/commit/238607ccdfa6b2025765c67a560199d890408d9c

It looks like there is a problems with default value of white-space handling mode in Ox. But not entirely - one failing test in multi_xml would remain. :-(

The problem with default value has been fixed later in Ox, but the latest Ox upstream version 2.5.0 is still problematic.

Reported here:

https://github.com/ohler55/ox/issues/179

We can revert the commit in Ox for Fedora. But upstream use to be pretty quick.

Sent pull-request to multi_xml upstream (one-line patch):

https://github.com/sferik/multi_xml/pull/60

bugs.title: CVE-2017-15928 rubygem-ox: Segmentation fault in the parse_obj

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2017-15928 rubygem-ox: Segmentation fault in the parse_obj

long_desc.thetext:
In the Ox gem 2.8.0 for Ruby, the process crashes with a segmentation fault when a crafted input is supplied to parse_obj.

Upstream issue:

https://github.com/ohler55/ox/issues/194

Upstream patch:

https://github.com/ohler55/ox/commit/e4565dbc167f0d38c3f93243d7a4fcfc391cbfc8

Created rubygem-ox tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: epel-7 [bug 1509283]
Affects: fedora-all [bug 1509284]

This could be probably closed? Fedora has the new version with the fix, EPEL 7 has the patch backported.

Quit check for this issue:

ruby -rox -e 'Ox.parse_obj("<k><s></s></k>")'

This CVE Bugzilla entry is for community support informational purposes only as it does not affect a package in a commercially supported Red Hat product. Refer to the dependent bugs for status of those individual community products.
